abstracts.cdata!:
The project achieved its overall
            objectives: project outcome was, therefore, satisfactory.
            Project sustainability is likely. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances are rated satisfactory overall.
            Lessons learned included the following: Although Mexico
            suffered one of its most severe economic crises, the
            Government decided to cut allocations for new construction
            and thus concentrate funds available for maintenance of the
            existing network--evidencing the Government's
            commitment towards the project's objectives. The
            project was fully satisfactory in introducing major changes
            in institutional arrangements. These results were the
            culmination of a long-term relationship between the Bank and
            the country, with continuity of the Bank's staff
            dedicated to Mexico, and enough time to prepare the project.
            Planning for the use of resources should be based on
            economic analysis that identifies the optimal choices of
            road sections to be improved and the type of works to be
            carried out, through the use of computerized road management
            systems. Contracting of maintenance on a competitive basis
            improves efficiency compared to force account operations; it
            should be used for all routine maintenance and periodic
            maintenance when there is sufficient knowledge regarding how
            this can be done. A good design is important in a program
            like this, in order to maximize the likelihood of a positive
            output, and get sufficient experience to progressively
            implement maintenance contracts based on performance.
